Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Assessing the Evolutionary Significance of Recurrent Horizontal Gene Transfer of a Chimeric Photoreceptor in Ferns
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will provide a deeper understanding of the systematics of ferns and the genes that allow them to grow in shady habitats. The presence of neochrome -- a novel chimeric photoreceptor that fuses red-sensing and blue-sensing photoreceptors into a single gene -- is linked to the ability of ferns to thrive in low-light conditions. Despite its potential importance in adaptation, the evolution of neochrome has remained unexplored. This study will investigate the evolution of neochrome and test the hypothesis that the distribution of the gene is the result of recurrent horizontal gene transfer among ferns. This award will support the research and training of a female doctoral student and undergraduate researchers in diverse molecular and systematic methods.

Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is common in prokaryotes and is often a key driver of adaptation and evolution. However, most documented examples of plant-to-plant HGT involve mitochondrial DNA and/or parasite-host transfers; only a handful of cases include functional nuclear genes, and even fewer have possible adaptive implications. Consequently, plant-to-plant HGT generally has been overlooked as a noteworthy factor in plant evolution. The aim of this research is to use targeted next-generation sequencing of neochrome from diverse fern species to further elucidate the frequency and timing of the seemingly large number of neochrome horizontal gene transfer events in ferns. Because neochrome may have played a major role in promoting the radiation of ferns under low-light environments, this study has important implications for better understanding the evolutionary significance of plant-to-plant HGT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ferns are well known for their shade-dwelling habits. Their ability to thrive under such low-light conditions has been linked to the evolution of a novel chimeric photoreceptor–neochrome–which fuses red-sensing phytochrome and blue-sensing phototropin modules into a single gene, thereby optimizing phototropic responses. Despite its potential importance in conferring a distinct evolutionary advantage to ferns living under dense canopies, the origin of neochrome has remained a mystery. We recently traced the origin of neochrome to hornworts (a bryophyte lineage), and showed that ferns acquired neochrome from hornworts via horizontal gene transfer (HGT). Subsequent phylogenetic analyses revealed a large-scale discordance between the fern neochrome gene tree and the fern species tree, suggesting rampant HGT occurred among ferns. The aim of this research is to examine the possible causes of the incongruent gene tree/species tree in ferns, and to evaluate the prevalence of neochrome HGT. 

Our previous approach to study neochrome HGT had been based on molecular cloning and transcriptome analyses. Although effective, this approach has difficulties to infer the mechanism of HGT, particularly whether the gene transfer was mediated by transposable elements. Therefore, we have embarked several fern whole genome sequencing projects. Two complete genome assemblies were done (Azolla filiculoides and Salvinia cucullata), and three others are ongoing (Dipteris conjugata, Pilularia americana and Adiantum shastense).

We are currently in the process of annotating the Azolla and Salvinia genomes, which will allow us to examine the extent of HGT in a genome-wide scale, and test whether the rampant neochrome HGT among ferns is an outlier or a common feature. Importantly, the completion of these two genomes–first in ferns–will advance not only our understandings of plant genome evolution, but also shed light on the origin of novel body plans in the plant tree of life. 

During the course of this study, we have also delved into the origin and evolution of phytochromes and phototropins, the parental photoreceptors of neochromes. We have found that the diversity of these photoreceptors is greater than expected especially among non-seed plants. With the discoveries of novel photoreceptor lineages and gene structures, it is now possible to integrate evolution, ecology and photobiology to understand how plants adapt to the ever-changing light environments. 

This research grant has provided the co-PI opportunities to mentor junior graduate students, and also work with science writers to broadly disseminate the research findings to the public. These experiences have been instrumental in advancing co-PI's career in academia. The co-PI is starting as a new assistant professor in Boyce Thompson Institute at Cornell University.
